Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Life after death - The role and composition of the thanatomicrobiome in the decomposition of mammalian organs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support for junior faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who need to re-direct and re-build a research program. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the researcher's home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences.

Alabama State University's (ASU) HBCU-UP RIA is aimed at systematically evaluating the role of the thanatomicrobiome (i.e., death-microbiome) in the decomposition of human organs. The goals of the proposed study are threefold: (i) to establish a working baseline of the thanatomicrobiome (blood, liver, spleen, heart and brain) of human cadavers that have known post-mortem intervals (PMIs) (i.e., the elapse time since actual death), (ii) to narrow down the number of sampling sites (blood, liver, spleen, heart and brain) to one/three in order to provide an in-depth assessment of the thanatomicrobiome in selected organs in many cadavers, (iii) identify the microbial community signatures that could be used to accurately determine PMI.

During the two-year project, the award supports four undergraduate and one master student in molecular biology, microbiology and bioinformatics STEM training. The project has the potential for local, regional and national impact as a collaboration with researchers at ASU, the University of Washington and the Alabama Department of Forensic Sciences, As a designated Experimental Program to Stimulate Research (EPSCoR) jurisdiction, the project broadens research capacity and capability in Alabama and contributes to preparation of a diverse workforce in the biological and computation sciences.

The project has the potential to lead to a tool that will assist in predicting the death interval for which, to date, no scientific method exists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Gulnaz Javan's HBCU-UP RIA at Alabama State University (ASU) was aimed at systematically evaluating the role of the thanatomicrobiome (i.e., death-microbiome) in the decomposition of human organs. The goals of the study that were completed were threefold: (i) the research established a working baseline of the thanatomicrobiome (blood, liver, spleen, heart and brain) of human cadavers that have known post-mortem intervals (PMIs) (i.e., the elapse time since actual death), (ii) the research narrowed down the number of sampling sites (blood, liver, spleen, heart and brain) to one/three in order to provide an in-depth assessment of the thanatomicrobiome in selected organs in many cadavers, (iii) the results identified the microbial community signatures that could be used to accurately determine PMI. Serveral outcomes of this project were disseminated to the scienfic community in a variety of ways.

We sampled corpses with varying times of death (range 3.5-240 hours), across multiple causes of death, using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing technologies to classify the microbial taxa associated with the organs of cadavers. Further, we demonstrated a significant correlation in the thanatomicrobiome signatures, which corresponded with PMI. Thus, we produced a microbial catalogue of the thanatomicrobiome, which may establish a useful forensic tool and provide constructive information to those who study human remains.

The results of this Life After Death project were disseminated in 22 peer-reviewed journal articles in journals such as Scientific Reports, Frontiers in Microbiology, and Forensic Science, Medicine and Pathology, among others. The results of this project were presented in 30 oral talks at international, national, regional, and local scientific meetings such as American Academy of Forensic Science (AAFS), Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference,  Black Doctoral Network (BDN), to name a few. Twenty posters were exhibited at international, national, regional, and local scientific meetings such as Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), CPU2AL Science and Technology Open House (STOH) Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR)  meeting, among others. Summaries of the results of this project were also published in six book chapters.

Dr. Javan won an international travel award to the 2017 Forensic Science Foundation (FSF) International Association of Forensic Sciences Scholarship ; she also was the recipient of 2015-2016 prestigious FSF Lucas Grant award.

Several prizes were awarded for student presentations of the results throughout the duration of this Life After Death project. Graduate student Zahra Campbell won a travel award to the 2016 ERN Conference. Graduate student Zahra Campbell also won the first place in Biological Sciences oral presentation award to the 2016 ERN Conference. Graduate student Sheree Finley won the student scholarship award from the Forensic Sciences Foundation to attend the Annual Meeting of the AAFS in 2017. Graduate student Sheree Finley won a travel award to the 2017 ERN Conference. Graduate student Sheree Finley also won the first place in Biological Sciences oral presentation award to the 2016 ERN Conference. Graduate student Alexis Morgan won a travel award to the 2019 ERN Conference.  Graduate student Shannon Pittman won a travel award to the 2019 ERN Conference.  Undergraduate student Marquis Nelson won a travel award to the 2019 ERN Conference.  Undergraduate student Gabrielle Maloy won the first place award in the undergraduate level at the STOH EPSCoR Conference poster contest in 2019. Undergraduate student Marquis Nelson won the first place award at the CSTEM Research Symposium poster contest in 2019.

Several undergraduate students were trained throughout the project: 2 PhD students Sheree Finley and Courtnee Bell; 15 MS students Ismail Can, Caleb Astin, Zahra Campbell, Diamond Kelly, Torri Thomas, Christina Dewberry, Asya Hammond, Tasia Smith, Frances Amber Hall, Trenisha Holmes,  Chanell Miles, Dequandra Belser, Mariah Tolbert, Shacole  Hayes, Alexis Morgan, Shannon Pittman; and 30 undergraduate students.
